parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post information.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>False. The post does not refer to any specific parliamentary candidate by name, surname, or any other clear identifier.  It encourages voting but doesn't endorse any particular candidate or party.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid Facebook advertisement, inherently designed to reach a wide audience. The targeting parameters (age, gender, location) further confirm this.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>The post's objective is not to directly influence votes for a specific candidate. While it encourages voting, it does so in the context of supporting women's access to reproductive healthcare. This is a broader societal issue, indirectly related to political choices but not directly advocating for a specific candidate or party. The call to action links to a website with more information, not to a candidate's page.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>The post could be considered a form of advocacy journalism or citizen journalism. It raises awareness about a social issue and encourages civic engagement (voting) as a means to address it.  It does not present itself as objective news reporting, but rather as an opinion piece promoting a cause.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>While the post expresses a viewpoint on a social issue, it does not present itself as a personal opinion unrelated to the election.  The call to action to vote links the issue to the electoral process, but not to a specific candidate.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>3081205278686790</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The post promotes voting to support women's access to reproductive healthcare. While indirectly related to the political process, it does not explicitly endorse any parliamentary candidate or party. The post's primary focus is on a social issue, using voting as a means to achieve a broader goal.  The lack of specific candidate mention, combined with the focus on a broader social issue, suggests that it does not meet the criteria for electoral propaganda under Article 98 t).  The paid nature of the post and its wide reach are factors to consider, but they do not automatically classify it as electoral propaganda if the content itself does not directly advocate for a specific candidate or party.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>Centrul FILIA</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
